RTCIceCandidateStats.summary: The RTCIceCandidateStats dictionary of the WebRTC API is used to report statistics related to an .

remarks.para: The statistics can be obtained by iterating the returned by until you find a report with the type of local-candidate.

RTCIceCandidateStatsUrl.summary:
The dictionary's
url property specifies the URL of the
ICE server from which the described candidate was obtained. This
property is only available for local candidates.
RTCIceCandidateStatsUrl.value:
A string specifying the URL of the ICE server from which the
candidate described by the RTCIceCandidateStats was obtained. This is the
same URL that would be received in the event's
property.
NOTEThis property does not exist for remote candidates.

RTCIceCandidateStatsFoundation.summary: NOTE Experimental The foundation property of the interface is a string that allows correlation of candidates from a common network path on multiple objects.

remarks.para: It is the same for two candidates that are of the same type, are using the same transport protocol, originate from the same IP address, use ports that fall within the same range, and come from the same STUN server.

RTCIceCandidateStatsFoundation.value: A string representing the of the corresponding .

RTCIceCandidateStatsPriority.summary: The priority property of the dictionary is a positive integer value indicating the priority (or desirability) of the described candidate.

remarks.para: -{{RFC(5245, "", "4.1.2.1")}}: Recommended Formula section in the ICE specification

RTCIceCandidateStatsPriority.value:
A positive integer indicating the priority of the described by the RTCIceCandidateStats object.
The value may be anywhere from 1 to 2,147,483,647.

RTCIceCandidateStatsTransportId.summary: The transportId property of the dictionary is a string that uniquely identifies the transport that produced the from which information about this candidate was taken.

remarks.para: This can be used, for example, to compare candidates that use the same transport.

RTCIceCandidateStatsTransportId.value: A string whose value uniquely identifies the transport from which any transport-related information accumulated in the was taken.

RTCIceCandidateStatsRelayProtocol.summary:
The dictionary's
relayProtocol property specifies the protocol being used
by a local ICE candidate to communicate with the TURN
server.

remarks.para:
The ICE protocol being used by the candidate otherwise can be obtained from the
property.

RTCIceCandidateStatsRelayProtocol.value:
A string identifying the protocol being used by the endpoint to
communicate with the TURN server. The possible values are:
NOTEThis property is only present on
objects that represent local candidates.

RTCIceCandidateStatsDeleted.summary:
The dictionary's
deleted property indicates whether or not the candidate
has been deleted or released.
RTCIceCandidateStatsDeleted.value:
A Boolean value indicating whether or not the candidate has been deleted or released.
If this value is true, the candidate described by the
object is no longer under consideration. The exact
meaning varies depending on the type of candidate:The net result is the same; the candidate is no longer under consideration if this
value is true.

RTCIceCandidateStatsCandidateType.summary: The candidateType property of the dictionary is a string that indicates the type of {{Glossary("ICE")}} candidate the object represents.
RTCIceCandidateStatsCandidateType.value: A string whose value is one of the strings found in RTCIceCandidate.type.

RTCIceCandidateStatsProtocol.summary: The protocol property of the dictionary indicates the protocol the specified candidate would use for communication with the remote peer.
RTCIceCandidateStatsProtocol.value: The value is one of the following strings:

RTCIceCandidateStatsAddress.summary:
The address property of the dictionary indicates the address of the {{Glossary("ICE")}} candidate.
While it's preferred that the address be specified as an IPv4 or IPv6 numeric address, a fully-qualified domain name can be used as well.

remarks.para: When a domain name is specified, the first IP address selected for that address is used, even if the domain name maps to multiple IP addresses.

RTCIceCandidateStatsAddress.value: Either an IPv4 or IPv6 address or a fully-qualified domain name, which corresponds to the candidate.

RTCIceCandidateStatsType.summary: The type property of the dictionary is a string with the value "local-candidate".

remarks.para:
Different statistics are obtained by iterating the object returned by a call to .
The type indicates the set of statistics available through the object in a particular iteration step.
A value of "local-candidate" indicates that the statistics available in the current step are those defined in .

RTCIceCandidateStatsPort.summary: The port property of the dictionary specifies the network port used by the candidate.
RTCIceCandidateStatsPort.value:
An integer value indicating the network port used by the described by this RTCIceCandidateStats object.
Corresponds to .

RTCIceCandidateStatsUsernameFragment.summary: NOTE Experimental The usernameFragment property of the interface is a string that represents the {{Glossary("ICE")}} username fragment ("ice-ufrag").

remarks.para: The fragment uniquely identifies a single ICE interaction session, and can be used to identify communications that are part of the same session even across ICE restarts.

RTCIceCandidateStatsUsernameFragment.value: A string representing the of the corresponding .

RTCIceCandidateStatsId.summary: The id property of the dictionary is a string that uniquely identifies the object for which this object provides statistics.

remarks.para: Using the id, you can correlate this statistics object with others, in order to monitor statistics over time for a given WebRTC object, such as an , or an .

RTCIceCandidateStatsId.value: A string that uniquely identifies the object for which this RTCIceCandidateStats object provides statistics.The format of the ID string is not defined by the specification, so you cannot reliably make any assumptions about the contents of the string, or assume that the format of the string will remain unchanged for a given object type.

RTCIceCandidateStatsTimestamp.summary: The timestamp property of the dictionary is a object specifying the time at which the data in the object was sampled.
RTCIceCandidateStatsTimestamp.value: A value indicating the time at which the activity described by the statistics in this object was recorded, in milliseconds elapsed since the beginning of January 1, 1970, UTC.The value should be accurate to within a few milliseconds but may not be entirely precise, either because of hardware or operating system limitations or because of fingerprinting protection in the form of reduced clock precision or accuracy.
